vision: Amtrak would like to evaluate its WIMS inventory system that is used to manage their 11 Commissaries to support their Food and Beverage operations onboard their train network. The platform is given train route and passenger levels with considerations for meal requirements, i.e. vegan or special events. The trains may run a combination of routes that put them outside of the commissary network, requiring them to ensure they top off inventory to handle the entire route. This platform also communicates with other systems such as pick to light, and potentially voice pick in the future. This system analysis should establish an as-is state, documenting existing capabilities, baselining operations, and capture any future capabilities or challenges. This should also involve processes to review operations at each commissary to collect as-is state, document and validate documentation of operations, and vision and scope of current and potentially future operating and systems procedures.
scope: To establish an inventory and "As-Is" state of systems, processes, and operating procedures used in the execution. This will also include benchmarking existing operational and systems efforts to their overall impact of P&L of Food and Beverage operations from a cost of goods sold perspective. Create project plan to execute and finally report to operations on findings and potential program roadmap.

requirements.text: The system must allow for real-time inventory tracking of all food and beverage items at each commissary.
requirements.benefit: Reduces out-of-stock situations by 30%.
requirements.objective: Ensure continuous availability of inventory.
requirements.value: Minimizes missed sales opportunities and improves customer satisfaction.
requirements.useCase: A commissary manager checks the real-time inventory levels before loading supplies onto a train.

questions.text: How often do trains run routes that require inventory top-offs?
questions.answer: Its based on the routes of the trains, some trains will travel multiple times between 2 points, such as Milwaukee to Chicago, where they would top off after a round trip if needed. Because this route is repeated, sometime the timing of the top off can impact if they can do it or not.

questions.text: What is the current level of automation in the inventory management process?
What are the current limitations of the WIMS platform in terms of real-time data synchronization across multiple commissaries?
options: Data transfer speed is too slow.
Lack of robust error handling in data syncing.
Incompatibility with different hardware at commissaries.

questions.text: How do staff currently handle inventory updates, and what tools do they use?
options: A combination of manual and digital tools.
Direct updates through WIMS platform interface.
Mobile devices with third-party inventory apps.
questions.answer: Not known at this point, this should be captured as a task

requirements.benefit: Reduces discrepancies in inventory counts and improves stock management accuracy.
requirements.objective: To enhance the reliability and timeliness of inventory data.
requirements.value: Enables better decision-making regarding stock replenishment and reduces overstocking or stockouts.
requirements.useCase: A manager at Commissary #3 checks the inventory levels of canned goods to decide on immediate restocking.

questions.text: What are the primary goals for the future of the WIMS system?
questions.answer: The WIMS platform is currently a COTS solution, Amtrak does not have access to the code and changes need to be made by the vendor. The WIMS platform was hosted in the Amtrak datacenter and will be moved to cloud service, however many of the technical architecture is dated and most like does not meet a structure that can be securely hosted in the close. This is being evaluated on a separate track. This process will ultimately support either enhancing WIMS or considering other solutions. This process is to help give a more realistic analysis of the current state and potential identify a roadmap going forward.

questions.text: How should we categorize the documentation to ensure it's both comprehensive and easily navigable?

requirements.benefit: Decreases the risk of stockouts by alerting staff in advance.
requirements.objective: To prevent inventory shortages and ensure product availability.
requirements.value: Improves customer satisfaction by ensuring product availability and reduces emergency purchasing costs.
requirements.useCase: An automated alert notifies the manager at Commissary #8 when the stock of a popular item falls below the minimum threshold.

requirements.value: Increases productivity of inventory staff, allowing for more accurate and timely updates.
requirements.useCase: A staff member at Commissary #6 uses the mobile app to scan and update inventory while performing a physical stock check in the storeroom.

questions.text: What are the current methods used for tracking inventory at each commissary?
questions.answer: The existing WIMS platform is responsible for all inventory at all 11 commissaries.

questions.text: What is the average inventory consumption per trip for different routes?
options: Consumption is relatively stable for short routes.
Longer routes have higher consumption rates.
No significant difference noted between routes.

questions.text: What are the key metrics that stakeholders would like to see on the dashboard?
questions.answer: The greatest concern is the impact of overall sales compared to cost. The staff is on a union contract, so the relative cost is an somewhat known cost level. Based on these resource costs, sales needs to reach at least a level to create at least a breakeven scenario. They will need to track gross and net along with a resource and material cost factor.

requirements.text: Implement a system to track the number of trips a train makes on a specific route to determine when inventory top-offs are necessary.
requirements.benefit: Reduce the frequency of unexpected stops for inventory replenishment by predicting needs.
requirements.objective: Increase operational efficiency and reduce downtime.
requirements.value: Enhances service reliability and reduces operational costs.
requirements.useCase: A train traveling between Milwaukee and Chicago multiple times per day would have its inventory tracked to schedule top-offs efficiently.

requirements.text: Develop an alert system within the train management software to notify when a train is due for an inventory top-off based on route frequency.

questions.text: How detailed are the existing documentation of operational procedures?
questions.answer: Very limited, documentation was not strongly created, and knowledge exists in the current staff, however this system is over 15 years old and attrition is impacting this tribal knowledge.

requirements.text: The documentation system must be accessible via a traditional Word document format for offline use and editing.

requirements.text: Integrate the existing third-party inventory management system (Aramark SOP) into the application for real-time inventory tracking.

requirements.objective: To automate and streamline inventory tracking processes.
requirements.value: Enhances accuracy, reduces operational costs, and improves inventory turnover.
requirements.useCase: Staff can view and manage inventory levels directly from the application.

requirements.text: Develop a feature to log and report discrepancies between physical inventory counts and system records.
requirements.benefit: Improves accuracy in inventory tracking and reduces theft or loss.
